choices.text: Color of the Human Skin depends upon the Number of Melanocytes
Melasma in Pregnancy is called as Chloasma
The Ratio of the Epidermal Melanin Unit is 36 Keratinocytes: 1 Melanocyte
Bindi Leukoderma is caused by Para-Tertiary Butyl-Phenol (PTBP)

questions.text: Identify the INCORRECT statement among the following options?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Color of the Human Skin depends upon the Number of Melanocytes.

 

Option A: Color of the human skin depends upon the number of melanocytes

 

The color of the human skin does NOT depend on the number of melanocytes.

 

The following factors determine the skin's color:

 

  1. The concentration of melanin within melanocytes
  2. The quantity and size of melanosomes
  3. The extent to which melanin is transferred into keratinocytes.

 

Melanin, a pigment produced by melanocytes, is what gives skin its color.

 

Melanocytes are dendritic cells that are found in the stratum basale layer of epidermis and are descended from neural crest cells.

 

The cell organelles known as melanosomes are where each melanocyte stores the melanin it produces.

 

Explanation:

 

Option C: These melanosomes are distributed to the 36 keratinocytes that make up the "epidermal melanin" unit via the dendritic processes of melanocytes. (The ratio of the epidermal melanin unit is 36 keratinocytes: 1 melanocyte)

 

Option B: Melasma in pregnant women is called as Chloasma or mask of pregnancy.

 

Clinical Image depicting Melasma

 

 

  • The third trimester of pregnancy is when chloasma is most prevalent and is most noticeable in brunettes.
  • It results from elevated levels of estrogen and progesterone stimulating melanocyte activity.
  • Histopathology shows no increase in number but hyper-functional melanocytes. Once the pregnancy is over, it resolves naturally.
  • The most frequent cause of chronic facial melanosis is melasma. Hyperpigmented macules that are more pronounced after exposure to sunlight are its primary symptom. Upper lip, malar, forehead, and chin are the main areas of the body affected by this hyper melanosis. Women between the ages of 20 and 40 are more likely to have it.
  • It is due to increased levels of estrogen & progesterone, stimulating the activity of melanocytes. Histopathology shows no increase in number but hyper functional melanocytes. It resolves on its own after pregnancy.
  • It is frequently seen in women on OCPs.

 

Woods lamp examination is useful to differentiate various types of Melasma, level of pigmentation & treatment response:

 

 

  • Melasma is more Chronic & requires treatment with depigmenting agents like:
  • Kligman triple combination- Topical Hydroquinone + Tretinoin + Steroid compound cream (First Line)
  • Hydroquinone (reduces Tyrosinase Activity)
  • Kojic Acid (Tyrosinase Inhibitor)
  • Chemical peels

 

Option D: Para-Tertiary Butyl Phenol is the culprit behind bindi Leukoderma (PTBP). It is present in adhesive sticker Bindi.

 

Clinical Image depicting Bindi Leucoderma

 

 

  • This condition is known as chemical or contact leukoderma, in which the chemical increases sensitivity and causes the melanocytes in the area of contact to undergo apoptosis.
  • Additionally, there is proof that azo dyes, which share structural similarities with tyrosine and compete with it for the binding of the tyrosinase enzyme, can directly inhibit melanogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct identification of skin colour being determined by melanin production and NOT by the number of melanocytes is crucial for understanding the pathophysiology of pigmentary disorders.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page No 2.17, 68.11, 75.19, 88.10

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 1119-1121

choices.text: Loss of Melanocytes is the pathological basis for the given Skin condition
This condition has the Strongest association with Thyroid Disorders
﻿Positive Family History, Mucosal Involvement & Positive Koebner's Phenomenon are Bad Prognostic Factors for this condition
Cyclosporine is a Treatment Option for this condition

questions.text: A 24-year-old college student presented to the OPD with depigmented patch on the back, in which some white hairs were also present. The lesion is stable for the past one year. Wood's lamp examination showed milky white fluorescence. Which of the following statements is INCORRECT among the options below regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cyclosporine is a Treatment Option for this condition.

 

Option D. Cyclosporine is a Treatment Option for this condition.

 

The image along with the woods lamp finding is suggestive of vitiligo.

 

Option D: Vitiligo cannot be treated with cyclosporine. There is inadequate proof of its advantages, and there are more possible adverse effects.

 

Treatment options for Vitiligo:

 

﻿Topical Agents:

 

  • ﻿Topical Corticosteroids
  • ﻿Calcineurin Inhibitors - Tacrolimus
  • ﻿Vitamin D Analogs - Calcitriol

 

Systemic Agents:

 

  • ﻿Corticosteroids
  • ﻿Azathioprine

 

Phototherapy:

 

  • ﻿PUVA
  • ﻿PUVASol - Sunlight
  • ﻿NBUVB - Narrow Band UV B Radiation at 311nm
  • ﻿Targeted Phototherapy using Excimer Laser 308nm

 

 ﻿Surgical Treatment:

 

  • ﻿Ultrathin Partial Thickness Skin Grafting
  • ﻿Non-Cultured Autologous Melanocytic Transfer
  • ﻿Cultured Autologous Melanocytic Transfer

 

Indications for Surgical treatment in vitiligo:

 

  1. Patients with stable vitiligo (a period of disease inactivity ranging from six months to two years)
  2. Vitiligo patients who failed to respond to non-surgical treatment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The pathological basis of vitiligo is the loss of melanocytes.

 

Studies using electron microscopy support the loss of melanocytes. An examination of the Wood's lamp reveals milky-white fluorescence.

 

  • Vitiligo is a common form of localized depigmentation. Vitiligo is distinguished by its clearly defined depigmented macules. It is an autoimmune condition brought on by the body's destruction of the dopa-positive melanocytes that make up the basal layer of the epidermis.
  • Vitiligo can appear at any age, but it typically first manifests itself in the third decade of life. Most likely, there is no difference in prevalence between the sexes or only a slight female preponderance.

 

The gradual loss of melanocytes causes a localized depigmentation to take place. It is categorized as.

 

  • Segmental vitiligo- which appears as unilateral depigmented macules in a segmented or band-shaped pattern.
  • Non-segmental vitiligo- which appears as bilateral macules distributed in an acrofacial pattern or scattered symmetrically over the entire body.

 

Koebner or isomorphic phenomenon:

 

It is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have iso (same), morphic (morphology) as existing lesions.

 

The image below shows vitiligo that exhibits the Koebner phenomenon:

 

 

 

Option B: Strongest association of vitiligo is with Autoimmune thyroid disorders (hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism).

 

Other disorders associated with vitiligo are:

 

  • ﻿Pernicious anemia
  • ﻿Addison's disease
  • ﻿Diabetes type I
  • ﻿Myasthenia gravis
  • ﻿Alopecia areata
  • ﻿Uveitis
  • ﻿Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • ﻿Autoimmune polyendocrine syndromes (types I and II)

 

Option C: Poor prognostic factors for vitiligo:

 

  • ﻿Positive family history
  • ﻿Mucosal vitiligo
  • ﻿Lesions over bony prominences
  • ﻿Isomorphic Koebner's phenomenon
  • ﻿Non-segmental vitiligo

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The association between vitiligo and various prognostic factors and treatment options is essential for the management of this condition.
  • The correct identification of these factors can help guide treatment decisions.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page No’s 21.1-21.4, 70.4 and 70.5

choices.text: Nevus Anemicus

questions.text: All of the following are associated with Hyperpigmentary Skin changes except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nevus Anemicus

 

Option C. Nevus Anemicus / Pharmacologic Nevus is a Hypopigmentary skin disorder, not a Hyperpigmentary condition.

 

  • It occurs due to increased sensitivity of local cutaneous blood vessels to catecholamines such as epinephrine (adrenaline) and norepinephrine (noradrenaline).
  • Because of this hypersensitivity, there is ongoing vasoconstriction, which causes hypopigmentation.
  • The term "pharmacologic nevus" is also used to describe it.

 

Image depicting Nevus Anemicus:

 

 

It is a congenital, localized, cutaneous vascular anomaly presenting as a pale, irregularly shaped patch on otherwise normal skin. There are no abnormalities in the melanocytes or the melanization, according to histology and electron microscopy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: certain drugs are associated with Hyperpigmentary skin changes. Minocycline is one among them, causing Blue black pigmentation in Acne scars as shown in the image below.

 

 

Drugs causing Hyper melanosis: 

 

 

Option B: When exposed to UV rays, melanocytes produce more melanin, which results in freckles or ephelides (with a normal number of melanocytes).

 

Image depicting freckles or ephelides:

 

 

It has an autosomal dominant pattern of transmission. They are observed in a variety of inherited and acquired diseases, such as progeria, neurofibromatosis, and xeroderma pigmentosum.

 

Fitzpatrick Classification type 1 and type 2 skin types both frequently have freckles.

 

First-line treatment is the use of a high SPF sunscreen.

 

Option D: Hyperthyroidism may cause generalized hyperpigmentation.

 

Generalized Hyper melanosis or hyperpigmentation can be due to a variety of systemic diseases. A few common diseases are mentioned below:

 

Systemic causes of hyperpigmentation

 

  • Cushing disease, addisons, grave's disease
  • Hemochromatosis
  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Pernicious anemia
  • Pregnancy
  • Renal failure
  • Systemic sclerosis

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nevus anemicus is associated with hypopigmentation, not hyperpigmentation, making it the correct answer.
  • Minocycline can cause hyperpigmentation, freckles are a form of hyperpigmentation due to increased melanin, and Addison's disease leads to hyperpigmentation due to increased MSH production.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume III Chapter 88 Page nos 88.14-16, 88.25 and 88.26

choices.text: Nevus of Ito
Nevus of Ota
Mongolian spots

questions.text: All of the following are examples of Dermal melanocytosis Ceruloderma except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Beckers nevus

 

Option D: Beckers nevus

 

This is not an example for dermal melanocytosis / Ceruloderma.

 

Option D: It is an epidermal melanocytic naevus with aggregation of melanocyte clusters in the epidermis. It is often hairy. The onset is around adolescence when there is an increased sensitivity to androgens especially in the distribution of outer arms, scapular area and chest.

 

 

A triad of features can be seen:

 

  1. Hyperpigmentation
  2. Hypertrichosis
  3. Acne

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Nevus of Ito: It affects the acromioclavicular region and upper chest. It primarily occurs in Chinese and Japanese people.

 

Skin affected is innervated by posterior supraclavicular and lateral cutaneous brachial nerves.

 

Nevus of Ito:

 

 

Option B: Naevus of Ota is more commonly seen in females.

 

It is a severe case of dermal melanocytosis that is bluish and patchy. Scattered among collagen bundles, mostly in the superficial dermis, are numerous elongated dendritic melanocytes.

 

Naevus of Ota:

 

 

The sclera and the skin around the eye are both impacted. It is distributed along the first and the second branches of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Most lesions appear at birth or during the first year of life, and they get bigger and more numerous as time goes on. Asians are more likely to develop these lesions.

 

Pigment targeting Q-switched laser systems is the treatment of choice for nevus of Ota & Ito.

 

Option C: Mongolian spots

 

These are congenital macular areas of blue-grey pigmentation of varying size and shape located on the lumbosacral area in normal infants. The lesion appears during pregnancy, grows during early childhood, and then disappears. Occasionally, it might continue into adulthood.

 

Mongolian spots:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Becker's nevus is not an example of dermal melanocytosis, but an epidermal nevus characterized by hyperpigmentation and possible hypertrichosis, distinguishing it from Nevus of Ito, Nevus of Ota, and Mongolian spots, which are all examples of dermal melanocytosis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 75.20

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 1189

choices.text: ﻿﻿Tyrosinase Enzyme Deficiency
﻿﻿Photophobia is an important complaint
﻿﻿Autosomal Dominantly Inherited
﻿﻿Melanocytes are Normal

questions.text: All of the following are true about the condition shown in the below image EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Autosomal Dominantly Inherited

 

Explanation:

 

Oculocutaneous Albinism:

 

  • This is a rare autosomal recessive disorder (NOT Autosomal Dominant) characterized by generalized depigmentation of the skin, hair, and eye.
  • Anomalies related to the eyes are also noted.
  • Melanocytes are normally present and distributed, but it is caused by a deficiency in melanin biosynthesis.
  • Tyrosinase gene (TYR) mutations are the cause of it.
  • There may be significant photophobia. Slit-lamp examination demonstrates iris translucency.
  • Sun protection is required to prevent skin cancer and sunburns, with a focus on patients who reside in high UV risk areas.
  • It is required to refer patients to an ophthalmologist early. Dark glasses are important to protect the eyes and prevent photophobia.

 

Educational Objective:

Albinism is typically inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, not autosomal dominant, and is characterized by a deficiency in the tyrosinase enzyme, leading to reduced or absent melanin production, normal melanocyte count, and associated photophobia.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 70.09

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page No 1095

choices.text: Autosomal Recessive Inheritance
Well-Defined Hyperpigmented Macules are seen
﻿﻿White Forelock is seen
Piebaldism along with Sensorineural Hearing Loss point towards ﻿﻿Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Piebaldism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) White Forelock is seen

 

Explanation:

 

Option C. Piebaldism is a Benign Autosomal Dominant (NOT AR) disease.

 

  • There are c-KIT Gene Mutations.
  • There are clearly defined, irregularly hypopigmented macules (NOT Hyperpigmented) that lack melanocytes.
  • The depigmented macules are related to Leucotrichia.
  • On normal skin or inside hypopigmented patches, small hyperpigmented spots can also be seen.
  • On the middle of the forehead, a V-shaped Leucoderma is frequently present.

 

Image below depicts White forelock in Piebaldism:

 

 

  • The remedy is skin or epidermal cell grafting.
  • The neonatal presence of white patches helps to distinguish Piebaldism from vitiligo.
  • Piebaldism along with sensorineural hearing loss point towards ﻿﻿ Waardenburg syndrome

 

Waardenburg syndrome: Autosomal dominant disorder having following characteristics:

 

  • White forelock
  • Hypopigmented patches
  • Heterochromia iridis
  • Sensorineural deafness

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Piebaldism is characterized by an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, well-defined hypopigmented macules, and a classic white forelock.
  • It is not related to Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, which has different clinical features, including gastrointestinal polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page No 70.3

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 1097

choices.text: Epidermal Verrucous Nevus
Congenital Melanocytic Nevus

questions.text: Identify the condition shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Congenital Melanocytic Nevus

 

Option B. Congenital melanocytic nevus

 

  • A child with a congenital melanocytic nevus is depicted in the picture.
  • Congenital melanocytic naevi should be by definition present at birth.
  • However, a small minority of lesions are either invisible or barely visible at birth, and then become clinically apparent as otherwise typical CMN in the first year of life – these are termed ‘tardive’.
  • They could be tiny or take up a lot of the surface area of the body.
  • Malignant Melanoma occurs more commonly in individuals with CMN. Melanoma risk may be increased by large (giant) nevi that are larger than 20 cm.
  • The median age for developing melanoma is approximately 7 years, so the relative risk in childhood is very high compared with the normal population where melanoma is virtually unknown in this age group.
  • Surgical excision is the mainstay of treatment, and a cultured epidermal autograft is used to cover large postoperative surface area defects.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Epidermal verrucous nevus:

 

  • An epidermal verrucous nevus is a type of skin lesion that appears as a warty, skin-colored or pigmented plaque.

 

 

  • It is usually present at birth or develops in early childhood and tends to have a verrucous (warty) surface, which is not apparent in the provided image.

 

Option C. Melanoacanthoma:

 

  • Melanoacanthoma is a rare, typically benign skin tumor that combines features of a melanocytic nevus and a seborrheic keratosis.

 

 

  • It often has a mixed pigmentation and a slightly raised appearance, unlike the smooth, consistent pigmentation of the lesion shown.

 

Option D: Malignant melanoma

 

  • While malignant melanoma is a dangerous form of skin cancer that can arise de novo or from a pre-existing mole, it generally presents with irregular borders, varying colors, and can have a rapid change in size.
  • The lesion in the image does not exhibit these malignant features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Melanocytic Nevus (CMN) by its presentation is a large, uniform, darkly pigmented, and well-defined birthmark, distinguishing it from verrucous nevi, melanoacanthoma, and malignant melanoma.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 75 Page No 75.14

questions.text: A 31-year-old lady presents complaining of facial discolouration. She is 26 weeks pregnant. So far it has been an uncomplicated pregnancy. On examination she has a large, flat, symmetrical, brown-pigmented patch across her cheeks, forehead, nose, and upper lip as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Melasma

 

Option B. Melasma, also known as chloasma or "mask of pregnancy,"

 

  • It is a common condition that occurs during pregnancy and is characterized by the development of symmetric, brownish patches on the face, particularly on the cheeks, forehead, nose, and upper lip.

 

 

  • It is related to hormonal changes and sun exposure and is a benign condition.
  • Melasma typically occurs in pregnant women and individuals with a family history of the condition.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)

 

  • It can present with a variety of skin manifestations, including a malar rash (butterfly rash) on the face.
  • However, the malar rash in SLE is typically more erythematous (red) than brown and is often associated with other systemic symptoms.
  • It is less likely in the absence of systemic symptoms and with a presentation of a large, flat, brown-pigmented patch.

 

Option C. Polymorphic eruption of pregnancy

 

  • It is also known as pruritic urticarial papules and plaques of pregnancy (PUPPP), is characterized by itchy urticarial papules and plaques that can occur during pregnancy.
  • It is different from the described pigmented patch on the face.

 

 

Option D. Rosacea

 

  • It is a chronic skin condition that primarily affects the face and is characterized by redness, visible blood vessels, and sometimes papules and pustules.
  • It does not typically present as a large, flat, brown-pigmented patch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a pregnant woman with a large, flat, symmetrical, brown-pigmented patch on the face, the most likely diagnosis is melasma.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page No 88.10

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 1119-1121

choices.text: True Koebner Phenomenon
False Koebner’s Phenomenon
Reverse Koebner Phenomenon
Remote Reverse Koebner Phenomenon

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to the clinic with multiple well-demarcated, depigmented patches over her elbows and knees. She mentions that the lesions appeared after she had a minor abrasion on her elbow and knees. Her medical history is significant for vitiligo but no other chronic diseases. Which of the following phenomena is most likely responsible for the appearance of her skin lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) True Koebner Phenomenon

 

Option A:

 

  • The Koebner Phenomenon refers to the development of skin lesions in areas of trauma or injury.
  • In vitiligo, the true Koebner phenomenon is observed, where depigmented patches may develop at sites of skin trauma, such as minor abrasions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. False Koebner’s phenomenon

 

  • This is related to the spread of infectious diseases such as viral warts and molluscum contagiosum along lines of trauma.
  • Since the patient has Vitiligo and there is no mention of infectious disease, this option is less likely.

 

Option C. The Reverse Koebner phenomenon

 

  • This refers to the clearing and healing of psoriatic lesions following injury.
  • This is not consistent with the patient's presentation, as she developed new vitiligo lesions after trauma, not clearance of existing lesions.

 

Option D. The Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

 

  • This involves the spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the sites of trauma, such as autologous skin graft sites.
  • This is not applicable to the patient's current situation, as there is no mention of repigmentation or recent skin grafts.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • True Koebner phenomenon in vitiligo, where depigmented patches may develop at sites of skin trauma, such as minor abrasions.
  • This phenomenon is distinct from the classic Koebner phenomenon seen in psoriasis.
  • Understanding these phenomena is essential for dermatologists in managing and counselling patients with vitiligo.

 

Ref: Bolognia Dermatology Textbook 4th Edition Page No 9

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page No 4.9

choices.text: Halo Nevus Phenomenon
Reverse Koebner Phenomenon

questions.text: Parents of a 2-year-old child present to the dermatology clinic with a skin lesion on the arm. Upon examination, the lesion is identified as a melanocytic nevus with a noticeable eczematous halo around it. The parents report that the halo developed a few weeks ago, and the child has been scratching the lesion since the appearance of halo. Which of the following best describes the observed dermatological phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Meyerson Phenomenon

 

Option D:

Meyerson phenomenon, which accurately describes the presentation of a melanocytic nevus with an eczematous halo around it.

 

  • This is characterized by an eczematous halo surrounding a melanocytic nevus.
  • Patients may present with itching and erythema around a pre-existing mole, as seen in the image provided.
  • This phenomenon is not associated with malignancy, and the management usually involves topical treatments for the eczema.

 

Explanation:

 

Option: A. The Halo nevus phenomenon

 

  • This typically refers to a melanocytic nevus surrounded by a depigmented halo, often considered to be an immune response where the body's immune system attacks the pigment cells in the mole.

 

 

  • It is not characterized by eczematous changes.

 

Option: B. The Reverse Koebner phenomenon

 

  • This refers to the clearing and healing of psoriatic lesions following injury.
  • This is not consistent with the patient's presentation, as It is not characterized by eczematous changes.

 

Option C: Sutton's phenomenon

 

  • This is also known as halo nevus, is similar to option A and describes a melanocytic nevus with a surrounding area of depigmentation, not an eczematous ring.

 

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Meyerson phenomenon, which refers to the eczematous halo surrounding a pre-existing skin lesion, often a nevus, with associated pruritus and erythema.

 

This phenomenon is distinct from the depigmented halo seen in a halo nevus.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page No 39.27

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 1108

questions.text: The most probable diagnosis for a young male presenting with Leucotrichia and lesions as depicted in the image is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Segmental Vitiligo

 

Option B. Segmental Vitiligo

 

  • Localized, unilateral depigmented macules can be seen in the image.
  • This characteristic and a history of leukotrichia point to the diagnosis of segmental vitiligo in the patient.
  • Vitiligo happens because the basal layer lacks melanocytes due to autoimmune destruction by auto antibodies.
  • The gradual loss of melanocytes causes a localized depigmentation to take place.

 

It is categorized as:

 

  1. Segmental vitiligo: This form of vitiligo is characterized by unilateral depigmented macules in a dermatomal or segmental pattern. The presence of Leucotrichia (white or colorless hair) within the lesion is a strong clinical indicator of segmental vitiligo. The image shows a pattern consistent with segmental vitiligo.
  2. Non-segmental vitiligo - which appears as bilateral macules distributed in an acrofacial pattern or scattered symmetrically over the entire body.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Focal vitiligo:

 

This is characterized by one or more macules or patches in one area without any recognizable pattern as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option C. Piebaldism:

 

  • It is a rare autosomal dominant disorder that is present at birth. The hallmark of piebaldism is a white forelock as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The distribution of lesions is usually symmetrical and remains stable throughout life, which differs from the presentation in the image.

 

Option D. Nevus depigmentosus:

 

  • This is a congenital, stable hypopigmented patch that does not progress or change with time.
  • Unlike vitiligo, it does not show Leucotrichia, and the lesion does not spread.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Segmental vitiligo presents with one or more macules in a dermatomal or segmental pattern, often accompanied by Leucotrichia.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of dermatology 9th Edition page no 88.34

questions.text: Match the following disorders of Hypopigmentation in column A with the Etiopathogenesis in Column B:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-d

 

Explanation:

 

Correct matches:

 

 

Here's the explanation for each match:

 

  • 1 Vitiligo: The Etiopathogenesis of Vitiligo is c. Melanocyte destruction by auto antibodies.
    • In Vitiligo, there is an autoimmune destruction of melanocytes, which are the cells responsible for producing melanin, the pigment that gives color to the skin. This leads to depigmented patches on the skin.
  • 2 Pityriasis Versicolor: The cause of this condition is a. Decrease in melanin synthesis.
    • Pityriasis versicolor is caused by a fungal infection which leads to a decrease in melanin synthesis due to the production of azelaic acid by the fungus, resulting in hypopigmented patches on the skin.
  • 3 Nevus Anemicus: The underlying mechanism is b. Vasoconstriction of blood vessels.
    • Nevus anemicus is a congenital disorder where there is localized vasoconstriction or decreased blood flow, giving the appearance of a hypopigmented patch. It is not due to a lack of melanocytes or melanin.
  • 4 Piebaldism: This condition is caused by d. Defect in migration of melanocytes from neural crest.
    • Piebaldism is a genetic disorder characterized by a congenital absence of melanocytes in affected areas of the skin and hair, due to a defect in the migration of melanocytes from the neural crest during embryonic development

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitiligo is caused by autoimmune destruction of melanocytes (c), Pityriasis versicolor is due to a decrease in melanin synthesis by fungal infection (a), Nevus anemicus involves vasoconstriction of blood vessels (b), and Piebaldism results from a defect in melanocyte migration from the neural crest (d).

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 32.12, 32.70, 70.3, 88.35

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 1087, 1097

choices.text: Post-Inflammatory Hyperpigmentation due to an Allergic Reaction

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with hyperpigmented facial lesions following a tropical vacation. She experienced a high fever, severe joint pain, and a diffuse rash a week after being bitten by mosquitoes. The fever and rash resolved, but the facial pigmentation persisted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chikungunya Fever

 

Option B: Chikungunya Fever:

 

  • This is the most likely diagnosis. Chikungunya Fever, transmitted by Mosquitoes, commonly presents with acute onset of fever, severe joint pain, and rash, which align with the patient's symptoms.
  • The "Chik sign" refers to the hyperpigmented lesions on the face, typically seen after the acute phase of the illness.
  • This patient's travel history to a tropical region and the symptomatology strongly suggests Chikungunya fever.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fixed Drug Eruption (FDE):

 

  • FDE typically presents as a solitary or few well-demarcated, round or oval, red or purple patches or plaques.

 

 

  • The lesions recur at the same site upon exposure to the offending drug.
  • The history of mosquito bites and tropical travel, along with the absence of a new medication, makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option C. Melasma:

 

  • Melasma is characterized by symmetrically distributed hyperpigmented patches, primarily on the face.

 

 

  • It is more commonly associated with sun exposure and hormonal changes rather than an infectious etiology.

 

Option D. Post-Inflammatory Hyperpigmentation due to an Allergic Reaction:

 

  • While this could cause facial pigmentation, the patient's history of fever, joint pain, and diffuse rash following a mosquito bite in a tropical region is more suggestive of a systemic infectious process rather than a localized allergic reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chikungunya fever in patients presenting with a history of fever, joint pain, and rash following travel to tropical regions, along with distinctive facial hyperpigmentation known as the "Chik sign."

 

Ref: Online resources:

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/327140731_%27Chik%27_Sign_in_Chikungunya_Fever

choices.text: Mono Benzyl Ether of Hydroquinone

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the clinic with a hypopigmented, round lesion on the middle of her forehead, as demonstrated in the accompanying image. There is no associated pruritus or scaling. She reports that the lesion appeared gradually over the past several months. She denies any use of topical creams or ointments prior to the onset of the lesion. On examination, the lesion is well-circumscribed with a diameter of approximately 1 cm. There is no evidence of erythema or induration. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this hypopigmentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Para Tertiary Butyl Phenol

 

Option C:

 

  • This is a Chemical Compound that can cause depigmentation of the skin due to its cytotoxic effects on melanocytes.
  • The Lesion shown is characteristic of chemical leukoderma, which is a skin condition caused by repeated exposure to specific chemical compounds leading to an acquired loss of pigmentation.
  • PTBP is often found in Adhesives and can cause this reaction upon skin contact (Bindi Leukoderma).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Hydroquinone

 

  • This is a topical agent used to lighten hyperpigmented skin areas.
  • Although it can cause hypopigmentation, it is typically used deliberately for cosmetic or therapeutic reasons and not typically associated with an unintended, isolated, round lesion as seen in the image.

 

Option B: Mono Benzyl Ether of Hydroquinone (MBEH)

 

  • This causes depigmentation and can be used therapeutically for extensive vitiligo.
  • However, it is not commonly associated with the sudden appearance of a single hypopigmented lesion like the one depicted.

 

Option D: Para Tertiary Butyl Catechol (PTBC)

 

  • This is another phenol derivative that can cause depigmentation.
  • However, it is less commonly encountered as a cause of chemical leukoderma compared to PTBP.

 

Chemicals Causing Chemical Leucoderma and Their Sources

 

 

Educational Objectives:

 

The most likely cause of the hypopigmented lesion in the middle of the forehead, as shown in the image, is exposure to Para Tertiary Butyl Phenol (PTBP), which is known to cause chemical leukoderma due to its cytotoxic effects on melanocytes.

 

Ref: Online sources:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2965911/

Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 4.4

choices.text: External Chemical Destruction of Melanocytes

questions.text: A 29-year-old female presents to the dermatology clinic with several depigmented patches on her hands and face as shown in the image below. There were white hairs seen in the depigmented patches. These patches have progressively enlarged over the past year. Which of the following is the most likely cause for the depigmentation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Absent Melanocytes

 

Option A: The diagnosis here is Vitiligo

 

  • This is characterised by the absence of melanocytes in the affected areas of the skin, which manifests as depigmented patches that may also involve the hair, resulting in white hair within the patches.
  • The presence of white hair (Leucotrichia) is indicative of a loss of melanocyte function in the hair follicles as well.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Defective Enzyme Tyrosinase

 

  • This is a feature of albinism, a genetic condition where melanin synthesis is impaired due to a defect in the tyrosinase enzyme.
  • In vitiligo, the enzyme is intact, but the melanocytes are absent.

 

Option C: Defective Migration of Melanocytes

 

  • This is seen in congenital conditions like piebaldism, where melanocytes do not migrate properly during development.

 

 

  • This is not a feature of vitiligo, which is an acquired condition.

 

Option D: External Chemical Destruction of Melanocytes

 

  • This may cause a depigmentation pattern similar to vitiligo, known as chemical leukoderma, but it is not associated with the spontaneous development of vitiligo.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hallmark of vitiligo is the absence of melanocytes in the skin, leading to depigmented patches, sometimes with white hair, distinguishing it from conditions related to enzyme defects, migration issues, or chemical exposure.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page No’s 88.35

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No’s 1088

questions.text: A patient presents to the clinic with a unilateral blue-brown speckled patch on her malar face. Histological examination from a biopsy of the lesion reveals an increased number of elongated, dendritic melanocytes scattered throughout the dermis, with a normal collagen pattern. Based on the clinical and histopathological findings, which of the following is the correct diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nevus of Ota

 

Option A: Nevus of Ota 

 

  • It is characterized by a blue or grayish pigmentation that typically affects the malar region of the face and is unilateral.

 

 

  • The presence of elongated, dendritic melanocytes scattered throughout the dermis is diagnostic of Nevus of Ota, which does not typically affect the collagen pattern.

 

Option B: Blue nevus

 

  • This is a benign melanocytic nevus that presents as a blue-colored papule or nodule due to the presence of melanocytes deep within the dermis.
  • However, it does not present as a speckled patch nor is it typically associated with the malar area.

 

Option C: Hypomelanosis of Ito

 

  • This is a neurocutaneous disorder characterized by whorls and streaks of hypopigmented skin, following the lines of Blaschko.
  • It does not present with an increase in melanocytes.

 

Option D: Sturge-Weber syndrome

 

  • This is a phacomatosis characterized by a port-wine stain (capillary malformation) on the face, leptomeningeal angiomas, and ocular abnormalities.
  • It is not associated with dendritic melanocytes in the dermis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Nevus of Ota is diagnosed by the clinical presentation of a unilateral blue-brown speckled patch on the malar face and histologically by an increased number of elongated, dendritic melanocytes in the dermis, without affecting the collagen pattern.

 

Ref: Rooks’ Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 73.2, 132.13

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 1961

questions.text: A 29-year-old female presents with blotchy hyperpigmentation on her cheeks and nose that developed during her recent pregnancy. The hyperpigmentation is symmetric and primarily involves the sun-exposed areas of her face. She reports that the pigmentation tends to worsen with sun exposure. She has no other significant past medical history and is not on any medications. Considering the history and clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chloasma

 

Option D: Chloasma

 

  • This is also known as melasma or the "mask of pregnancy," is characterized by symmetrical hyperpigmented patches that often occur during pregnancy. It typically affects sun-exposed areas of the face, and the pigmentation can be exacerbated by sun exposure.

 

 

  • It is thought to be related to hormonal changes during pregnancy and is more common in darker-skinned individuals.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Senile Lentigenes

 

  • These are also known as liver spots, are benign lesions that occur in older individuals due to chronic sun exposure.
  • They are not related to pregnancy and typically appear as small, well-defined spots.

 

Option B: Freckles

 

  • These are small, brownish spots on the skin that can be exacerbated by sun exposure but are usually present from a young age and not specifically associated with pregnancy.

 

 

  • Multiple freckles seen over face.

 

Option C: Nevi

 

  • Commonly known as moles, can vary in appearance but are typically well-demarcated growths on the skin that are not typically associated with pregnancy-related hormonal changes.

 

Differences between Freckles and Lentigines

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of chloasma is supported by the presentation of blotchy hyperpigmentation on the cheeks and nose that developed during pregnancy, worsens with sun exposure, and is not associated with aging, sun-induced freckles, or moles.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page No 88.10

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 1119-1121

questions.text: A 17-year-old male is referred to a genetics clinic after he presented with several episodes of abdominal pain and rectal bleeding. He has a history of frequent bowel movements containing blood since childhood. Physical examination reveals multiple, dark blue to brown macules on his lips and oral mucosa. His family history is significant for his father undergoing surgery for bowel obstruction in his thirties. Colonoscopy reveals multiple polyps throughout the colon. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome

 

Option D:

 

  • This is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation (typically dark blue to brown macules on the lips and oral mucosa) and gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps.
  • It results from a serine/threonine kinase gene mutation (STK11).

 

 

 

  • Hamartomatous polyps can be found anywhere along the GI tract, but they are most common in the jejunum.
  • Patients are at an increased risk for both gastrointestinal and extraintestinal malignancies.
  • The history of blood in the stool since childhood, mucocutaneous pigmentation, and a family history of bowel obstruction suggests a diagnosis of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.
  • Lip lentigines are typical cutaneous characteristics (early feature).
  • Associated melanocytic macules of the digits and buccal mucosa are typical.
  • Patients need lifelong screening because they are at a high risk for developing stomach, colon, breast, and ovarian cancers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

 

  • This is characterized by hundreds to thousands of adenomatous colon polyps, but it does not include the mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation seen in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

 

Option B: Cronkhite-Canada Syndrome

 

  • This is a non-hereditary condition characterized by gastrointestinal polyps, diarrhea, weight loss, and abnormalities of the hair and nails but not the distinctive pigmentation of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

 

Option C: Gardner Syndrome

 

  • This is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis that includes extracolonic features like osteomas and soft tissue tumors, but not the mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation that is diagnostic of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

 

Differences between Freckles and Lentigines

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome should be considered in patients with a personal and family history of gastrointestinal polyps, characteristic mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation, and an increased risk of gastrointestinal and extraintestinal malignancies.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 88.15, 110.13

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 832, 1955

choices.text: Congenital Melanocytic Nevus

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with a large, unilateral patch on his right shoulder that he has had since adolescence. He reports the area has become more pigmented and slightly hairy over the past few years. On examination, the patch is hyperpigmented and has a well-defined border, with an increase in terminal hairs within the same area. The lesion is non-tender, and there are no palpable masses. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Becker's Nevus

 

Option D:

 

  • This is a benign cutaneous hamartoma that is characterized by a unilateral, hyperpigmented patch that may become hairy (hypertrichosis), often becoming more prominent during puberty (Androgen dependent).
  • Onset:Acquired
  • Symmetry: Unilateral Lesion

 

 

  • It typically presents on the shoulder or upper trunk and is more common in males.
  • It can be associated with Ipsilateral breast hypoplasia
  • Number of melanocytes are normal.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Melasma

 

  • This presents as symmetrical, blotchy, brownish facial pigmentation and is common in women, particularly during pregnancy or when taking oral contraceptives.
  • It does not typically involve hypertrichosis.

 

Option B: Congenital Melanocytic Nevus

 

  • This is present at birth or shortly thereafter and can range from small to garment-like in size.

 

 

  • These lesions may have increased hair growth but are congenital, unlike the post-pubertal development of Becker's nevus.

 

Option C: Vitiligo

 

  • This is characterized by patches of depigmentation due to the loss of melanocytes and does not involve hypertrichosis or hyperpigmentation.

 

Comparison between Becker’s Nevus and Nevus of Ito

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Becker's nevus is suggested by the appearance of a unilateral, hyperpigmented patch with associated hypertrichosis, usually developing around puberty and located on the shoulder or upper trunk.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 75.20

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 1189

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents to the clinic with a history of frequent and severe pyogenic infections, albinism, and easy bruising. The child has silvery hair and photophobia. Physical examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly and neurological examination shows mild ataxia. A peripheral blood smear shows giant granules in granulocytes and platelets. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chediak-Higashi Syndrome

 

Option D: Chediak-Higashi Syndrome

 

  • This is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by oculocutaneous albinism, immunodeficiency leading to recurrent infections, bleeding diathesis, and neurological abnormalities.
  • The presence of giant granules in leukocytes and platelets on blood smear is highly suggestive of this condition.
  • It is caused by a defect in the LYST (lysosomal trafficking regulator) gene which affects phagosome-lysosome fusion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Griscelli syndrome

 

  • This also presents with partial albinism and immunodeficiency, but it is typically associated with mutations in the MYO5A, RAB27A, or MLPH genes and does not typically present with the giant granules found in leukocytes seen in Chediak-Higashi syndrome.

 

Option B: Hermansky-Pudlak Syndrome

 

  • This is another syndrome that presents with oculocutaneous albinism and a bleeding diathesis due to platelet dysfunction, but it does not feature the recurrent severe infections or neurological symptoms typical of Chediak-Higashi syndrome.

 

Option C: Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome

 

  • This is characterized by immunodeficiency, eczema, and thrombocytopenia, but it does not cause albinism or the presence of giant granules in white cells.

 

 

Characteristics of Various Syndromes

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Chediak-Higashi syndrome is based on the clinical triad of oculocutaneous albinism, recurrent pyogenic infections, and neurological symptoms, along with the characteristic finding of giant granules in leukocytes and platelets on peripheral blood smear.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 70.8

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 962

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with symmetric depigmented patches on the dorsum of foot, as shown in the image. The patches have well-defined margins and there is no associated itching or scaling. The patient reports that these patches first appeared several months ago and have slowly increased in size. On further questioning, the patient mentions using rubber slippers after which he noted these patches. In which of the following diseases is the chemical agent responsible for this presentation used as a treatment option in extensive disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitiligo

 

Option D:

 

  • The image shows depigmented patches that are consistent with rubber-induced chemical leukoderma, which resembles vitiligo but is due to an external cause, in this case, the chemical Mono-Benzyl Ether of Hydroquinone (MBEH) found in some rubber products.
  • MBEH can cause depigmentation by destroying melanocytes and is actually used therapeutically in extensive vitiligo to depigment remaining pigmented skin.

 

 

  • Michael Joseph Jackson (KING OF POP) before and after vitiligo images.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Piebaldism is a genetic condition characterized by a white forelock and stable depigmented patches present from birth, not acquired due to external agents like MBEH.

 

 

Option B: Pityriasis versicolor is a fungal infection that typically presents with hypo- or hyperpigmented scaly patches, not depigmentation due to melanocyte destruction.

 

Option C: Post-Inflammatory Hypopigmentation occurs after inflammatory skin conditions and is not induced by chemicals like MBEH, nor is it treated with such agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of depigmented patches as shown in the image is indicative of chemical leukoderma, specifically rubber-induced leukoderma, which can be caused by chemicals such as MBEH that are also used in the depigmentation process of Extensive vitiligo treatment.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 88.12, 88.45

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 1094

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3533321/
